The `name` parameter must be unique.

`address` must be a valid address including a scheme and port.
Currently only https and http are supported as scheme.

post.summary: Bruteforce subdomains through a DNS wordlist attack
post.description:
Bruteforce subdomains through a DNS wordlist attack

Enumerate possible subdomains by querying a DNS server with constructed domains.
See [OWASP](https://owasp.org/www-community/attacks/Brute_force_attack) for further information.

post.summary: Query a certificate transparency log collector.
post.description:
Query a certificate transparency log collector.

For further information, see [the explanation](https://certificate.transparency.dev/).

Certificate transparency can be used to find subdomains or related domains.

`retry_interval` is specified in milliseconds.

Start a tcp port scan

`exclude` accepts a list of ip networks in CIDR notation.

All intervals are interpreted in milliseconds. E.g. a `timeout` of 3000 means 3 seconds.

Set `max_retries` to 0 if you don't want to try a port more than 1 time.

get.description: Retrieve an attack by id

delete.summary: Delete an attack and its results
delete.description: Delete an attack and its results

get.summary: Retrieve a tcp port scan's results by the attack's id
get.description: Retrieve a tcp port scan's results by the attack's id

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: Position in the whole list to start retrieving from

post.summary: Finishes the authentication with a security key
post.description:
Finishes the authentication with a security key

Use `startAuth` to retrieve the challenge response data.

post.summary: Finish the registration of a security key
post.description:
Finish the registration of a security key

Use `startRegister` to retrieve the challenge response data.

get.description:
Log out of this session

Logs a logged-in user out of his session.

post.summary: Starts the authentication with a security key
post.description:
Starts the authentication with a security key

Use the `login` endpoint before calling this one.

Proceed with `finishAuth`.

post.summary: Start the registration of a security key
post.description:
Start the registration of a security key

Proceed to the `finishRegister` endpoint.

get.description:
Test the current login state

You can use this endpoint to test the current login state of your client.

If logged in, a 200 without a body is returned.
Retrieve all global tags

post.summary: Endpoint an application calls itself after the user accepted and was redirected back to it.
post.description: Endpoint an application calls itself after the user accepted and was redirected back to it.

get.summary: Endpoint visited by user to grant a requesting application access
get.description: Endpoint visited by user to grant a requesting application access

302.description: The user is redirected back to the requesting client

get.summary: Initial endpoint an application redirects the user to.
get.description:
Initial endpoint an application redirects the user to.

It requires both the `state` parameter against CSRF, as well as a pkce challenge.
The only supported pkce `code_challenge_method` is `S256`.

parameters.name: client_id
parameters.description: The client identifier as described in [Section 2.2](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc6749#section-2.2).

parameters.name: scope
parameters.description: The scope of the access request as described by [Section 3.3](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc6749#section-3.3).

parameters.name: state
parameters.description:
An opaque value used by the client to maintain
state between the request and callback.  The authorization
server includes this value when redirecting the user-agent back
to the client.  The parameter SHOULD be used for preventing
cross-site request forgery as described in [Section 10.12](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc6749#section-10.12).

302.description: The user is redirected to the frontend

get.summary: Endpoint visited by user to deny a requesting application access
get.description: Endpoint visited by user to deny a requesting application access

302.description: The user is redirected back to the requesting client

get.summary: Queried by the frontend to display information about the oauth request to the user
get.description: Queried by the frontend to display information about the oauth request to the user

200.description: Return information about an ongoing oauth request

get.description: Retrieve a workspace's attack results
Retrieve the own user

put.description:
Updates the own user

All parameters are optional, but at least one of them must be supplied.

get.summary: Retrieve all workspaces owned by executing user
get.description:
Retrieve all workspaces owned by executing user

For administration access, look at the `/admin/workspaces` endpoint.

200.description: Returns all workspaces owned by the executing user

get.description: Retrieve a workspace by id

put.summary: Updates a workspace by its id
put.description:
Updates a workspace by its id

All parameter are optional, but at least one of them must be specified.

`name` must not be empty.

You can set `description` to null to remove the description from the database.
If you leave the parameter out, the description will remain unchanged.

delete.summary: Delete a workspace by its id
delete.description: Delete a workspace by its id

get.description:
Retrieve all hosts.

Hosts are created out of aggregating data or by user input.
They represent a single host and can be created by providing an IP address

Start a websocket connection

A heartbeat PING packet is sent constantly (every 10s).
If no response is retrieved within 30s of the last transmission, the socket
will be closed.

ApiErrorResponse.description:
Representation of an error response

`status_code` holds the error code, `message` a human readable description of the error

ApiStatusCode.description:
This type holds all possible error types that can be returned by the API.

Numbers between 1000 and 1999 (inclusive) are client errors that can be handled by the client.
Numbers between 2000 and 2999 (inclusive) are server errors.

Pkce.description:
The client sends the code challenge as part of the OAuth 2.0
Authorization Request ([Section 4.1.1 of \[RFC6749\]](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc6749#section-4.1.1)) using the
following additional parameters:

QueryCertificateTransparencyRequest.description: The settings to configure a certificate transparency request

created_at.description: When the attack was created i.e. started

finished_at.description: When the leech signaled to be finished with the attack

tcp_port_scan_attacks.description: List of all tcp port scan attacks

attacker.description: List of user which started attacks in this workspace

ScanTcpPortsRequest.description: The settings to configure a tcp port scan

name.description: A descriptive name helping the user to identify the key

SimpleAttack.description: A simple version of an attack

SimpleHost.description: The simple representation of a host

uuid.description: The primary key of the host

ip_addr.description: The ip address of the host

workspace.description: The workspace this host is in

SimpleOauthClient.description: A simple (secret-less) version of a workspace

SimpleWorkspace.description: A simple version of a workspace

description.example: This workspace is ultra secure and should not be looked at!!

limit.description: The limit this page was retrieved with

offset.description: The offset this page was retrieved with

total.description: The total number of items this page is a subset of

expires_in.description: Duration in seconds the token is valid for

name.description: A descriptive name helping the user to identify the key

UserResponse.description:
This struct holds the user information.

Note that `username` is unique, but as it is changeable,
identify the user by its `uuid`

UuidResponse.description: A common response that contains a single uuid
